title-group.article-title: Acquisition, expression, and reinstatement of ethanol-induced conditioned place preference in mice: effects of exposure to stress and modulation by mecamylamine

abstract.p: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors mediate some of the rewarding and motivational effects of ethanol, including relapses. Relapses are common in drug addicts during abstinence when exposure to any stressor ensues. However, the role of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the ethanol- and stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol-induced conditioned place preference has not yet been explored. Therefore, the present study investigated the influence of mecamylamine, a nicotinic acetylcholine receptors antagonist on acquisition, expression, and reinstatement of ethanol-induced conditioned place preference in adult male Swiss mice. The results revealed that mecamylamine (0.1–10 µg/mouse, intracerebroventricularly) dose dependently prevented the development, expression, and reinstatement of ethanol-induced conditioned place preference. Further, acute treatment with mecamylamine blocked the restraint stress and forced swim stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol-induced conditioned place preference. All of these treatments had no influence on the locomotor activity. Therefore, it is concluded that mecamylamine blocks the acquisition, expression and reinstatement of conditioned reinforcing effects of ethanol without per se reinforcing or aversive influence. This ability of mecamylamine might be a potential advantage in the treatment of alcoholism.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Drug addiction is a chronic relapsing brain disorder characterized by neurobiological changes leading to compulsive drug-seeking and drug-taking behavior. One of the main problems in the treatment of addiction is the high rate of relapse to drug use even after a long period of abstinence (Fiore, 2000; Shalev et al., 2002). Such behavior ensues after permanent alterations in the brain architecture (Nestler, 2004).

Exposure to stress is a key factor in vulnerability to drug abuse. It is thought that stress exposure and alcohol intake are closely related, and are central to the etiology of alcoholism (Pohorecky, 1981). Numerous clinical studies report that exposure to stress can induce relapse to drug seeking (Lamon and Alonzo, 1997; Brady and Sonne, 1999; Sinha et al., 1999; Sinha, 2001). It is also reported that exposure to inescapable stressor (forced swim stress) potentiate ethanol-induced rewarding effects (Sperling et al., 2010).

The role of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in alcoholism is established in several electrophysiological, behavioral, and genetic studies (Larsson and Engel, 2004; Ford et al., 2009; Bhutada et al., 2010c, 2010d; Kamens et al., 2010). The role of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in ventral tegmental area and nucleus accumbens is well established in ethanol intake and preference, as well as ethanol-induced stimulation of the mesolimbic dopaminergic system (Nadal et al., 1998; Le et al., 2000; Soderpalm et al., 2000; Blomqvist et al., 2002; Chi and de Wit, 2003; Larsson and Engel, 2004; Young et al., 2005). Recent studies have also documented that nicotinic acetylcholine receptor antagonists block the relapse, namely ethanol drinking behavior (Kuzmin et al., 2009) and cue-induced relapse-like response in rats (Lof et al., 2007).

Relapse to drug consumption is the most difficult challenge in the treatment of addiction, and the neurobiological mechanisms that underlie the persistence of such behavior remain poorly understood. Evidence suggests a role of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol intake. Therefore, we hypothesized that nicotinic acetylcholine receptor signaling may mediate the stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol-induced conditioned place preference (CPP). This hypothesis was tested in an animal model of reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP in mice, as it is suggested to be useful for study of relapse behavior (Mueller and Stewart, 2000; Itzhak and Martin, 2002; Lu et al., 2005; Biala and Budzynska, 2006).

We have used mecamylamine in the present investigation to study the role of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in ethanol-induced CPP and its modulation by stress as mecamylamine is a negative allosteric modulator and non-competitive antagonist of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, having high affinity for the α4β2 subtype. In addition, mecamylamine is reported to reduce the subjective euphoria of ethanol in humans (Blomqvist et al., 1996; Chi and de Wit, 2003; Le et al., 2000) and has recently been approved for the treatment of nicotine addiction.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: Adult male Swiss albino mice (24–30 g), born and reared in the Animal House of the Agnihotri College of Pharmacy, Wardha, from a stock originally purchased from Shree Farm, Bhandara, India, were used in the present investigations. Mice were group housed (four per cage) in opaque polypropylene cages (28 cm × 21 cm × 14 cm) and maintained at 23 ± 2°C under 12:12 h light/dark cycle (light cycle: 08:00–20:00), with free access to standard rodent diet and tap water. Animals were naive to drug treatments and experimentation at the beginning of all of the experiments. Each experimental group comprised six to eight mice. Behavioral studies were carried out between 09:00 and 14:00 to minimize circadian influences (if any). Testing was carried out in a counterbalanced order with respect to the treatment conditions, in a noise-free room. All of the experiments were approved by the Institutional Animal Ethics Committee (IAEC), constituted for the purpose of control and supervision of experimental animals by Ministry of Environment and Forests, Government of India, New Delhi, India.

sec.title: Drugs and solutions
sec.p: Mecamylamine hydrochloride (Sigma-Aldrich Co, St. Louis, MO) and ethanol (Changshu Yangyuan Chemical, China) were dissolved in 0.9% saline. Mecamylamine was administered at a dose of 0.1–10 µg/mouse, intracerebroventricularly (i.c.v.), in a volume of 1 µl, on the basis of our preliminary studies and previous report (Zarrindast et al., 2001). Mecamylamine was administered by intracerebroventricular route to avoid the involvement of peripheral nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (if any) in the effects. The ethanol was administered at dose of 2 g/kg intraperitoneally (i.p.) in a volume of 12.5 ml/kg body weight, as this dose was previously demonstrated to induce CPP in mice (Risinger and Oakes, 1996; Maurice et al., 2003; Font et al., 2006, 2008; Bhutada et al., 2010a).

sec.title: Intracerebroventricular injection
sec.p: The intracerebroventricular cannulation was carried out as described previously (Bhutada et al., 2010b). In brief, mice were anesthetized with ketamine–xylazine combination (100 mg/kg and 5 mg/kg respectively, intramuscularly [i.m.]) and stainless steel cannulae (Becton Dickinson, India, 24 gauge) were stereotaxically implanted with coordinates from Paxinos and Franklin (AP –0.82 mm; ML +1.5 mm and DV +2.0 mm; related to bregma). Guide cannulae were secured to the skull using mounting screws and dental cement (Dental Products of India, Mumbai). A stainless steel dummy cannula was used to occlude the guide cannula when not in use. The animals were then allowed to recover for a week under an antimicrobial cover of cefotaxim (50 mg/kg/day, subcutaneously [s.c.]), during which they were habituated to the experimental conditions such as the transfer of the animal from the husbandry to the testing room, and removal and occlusion of guide cannula by dummy cannula to minimize non-specific stress (if any). Injections were made using a 5 μL Hamilton syringe (Hamilton, NV, USA) connected to an internal cannula (31 gauge) by polyethylene tubing with a volume of 1.0 μL was administered over a period of 60 s into the right lateral ventricle. The injection cannula was left in place for a further 60 s before being slowly withdrawn to avoid back flow. At the end of all i.c.v. experiments, a dilute India ink was injected (1.0 μL, i.c.v.) and animals were euthanized by pentobarbitone overdose. Only data from animals that showed a uniform distribution of ink into the lateral ventricles were used for statistical analyses. Less than 10% of the mice were eliminated from results because of inaccurate cannula placement or injection leakage.

sec.title: Conditioned place preference
sec.p: The CPP test was carried out using Swiss mice as described earlier (Font et al., 2008; Bhutada et al., 2010a). The CPP experiments were conducted in a three-chambered place conditioning apparatus connected to a digital recorder and housed in a light- and sound-attenuated chamber (VJ Instruments, Buldhana, India). Two (6.6” × 5”) conditioning chambers, one white with a rough floor and the other black with a smooth floor, were connected by a small (2.85” × 5”) central access chamber with gray walls and a smooth polyvinyl chloride floor. In addition, each chamber was equipped with a house light, with the luminance (40 lux) adjusted such that the environmental (visual and tactile) cues should not produce a significant baseline preference for a specific chamber. All chambers were separated by manually operated guillotine doors. The individual chamber activity was determined by photobeam breaks recorded by a digital recorder. The experiment was carried in different phases detailed below.

The experiment was performed according to a Pavlovian procedure and consisted of 5 phases conducted for 20 consecutive days using an unbiased procedure: (i) adaptation (day 1), (ii) conditioning with ethanol (days 2, 4, 6, and 8), and conditioning with vehicle (days 3, 5, 7, and 9), (iii) post-conditioning test on day 10; (iv) extinction phase (days 11 to 19), and (v) reinstatement phase on day 20 (Table 1).

caption.p: Representation of different phases of conditioned place preference test

fn.p: CPP, conditioned place preference test; NA, not applicable

sec.p: During the adaptation, mice were carried into the testing room, weighed and handled by the experimenter. This adaptation phase was intended to reduce the novelty and stress associated with handling and injections. During conditionings, mice received ethanol (2g/kg, i.p.) or vehicle (12.5 mL/kg, i.p.) 10 min before being placed into the respective arm (either black or white) of the apparatus for 5 min. The neutral zone was never used during conditioning and was blocked by guillotine doors. The ethanol dose and conditioning phase duration were selected on the basis of previous studies and the fact that they are known to induce place preference in Swiss mice (Risinger and Oakes, 1996; Font et al., 2006, 2008; Bhutada et al., 2010a). In the post-test period, an individual mouse was placed in the central chamber and had free access to all of the chambers for the duration of 5 min (test session), and total time spent in each chamber was recorded. The extinction procedure was carried out as per the method described earlier (Font et al., 2008; Shoblock et al., 2011) with slight modifications based on our preliminary studies. The extinction phase was similar to the conditioning phase in that it was carried out over 8 days, with 5-min conditioning sessions each day. During this phase, each mouse was administered with saline and confined to the drug-paired compartment for 5 min. On alternate days, animals were injected with saline and confined to the other compartment for 5 min. After the last day of the extinction phase, all animals were exposed to a new test session (extinction) on day 19. The reinstatement was performed 24 h after extinction test in the mice, which showed extinction (day 20). The animals were administered with various treatments or ethanol (1.0 g/kg, i.p.). This sub-conditioning dose of ethanol (1.0 g/kg, i.p.) is reported to reinstate the extinguished ethanol-induced CPP in mice (Shoblock et al., 2011). Ten minutes thereafter animals were subjected to CPP test (reinstatement) and time spent in each chamber was recorded. Time spent in the ethanol paired chamber was used for statistical comparisons.

sec.title: Induction of stress
sec.p: Mice were subjected to restraint stress by an earlier reported method (Umathe et al., 2008). In brief, a mouse was placed in a 50 mL cylindrical polypropylene tube and the open ends were covered with a wire net for adequate ventilation.

Mice were subjected to forced swim stress by a method described earlier (Bhutada et al., 2010b). Mice were placed in a glass cylinder (height: 35 cm; diameter: 17 cm) filled with water (25 ± 1°C) to a depth of 25 cm. The water depth was adjusted so that the animals must swim or float without their hind limbs or tail touching to the bottom.

sec.title: Experiment 1: effect of mecamylamine on the acquisition of ethanol-induced CPP
sec.p: To determine the effects of mecamylamine on the acquisition of ethanol-induced CPP, mecamylamine (0.1–10 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) or vehicle (saline) was injected in a volume of 1 µL, 10 min before each ethanol (2 g/kg, i.p.) conditioning on days 2, 4, 6, and 8. On day 10, animals were injected with saline and placed into the apparatus for 5 min, with free access to all chambers, and the time spent in each chamber was recorded as a test for conditioned place preference. In a separate study, to determine whether the effects of mecamylamine on ethanol-induced CPP were due to intrinsic aversive properties, mice were conditioned to mecamylamine or its vehicle, without ethanol, using the same procedure as above.

sec.title: Experiment 2: effect of mecamylamine on the expression of ethanol-induced CPP
sec.p: Separate groups of mice were conditioned to 2 g/kg ethanol as described above. On the test day (day 10), mice were pretreated with mecamylamine (0.1–10 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) or vehicle (saline) 10 min before saline injection. Ten min after saline injection, mice were subjected to CPP test.

sec.title: Experiment 3: effect of mecamylamine on the reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP
sec.p: A separate group of mice were conditioned to 2 g/kg ethanol or saline as described above and given a 5 min CPP test on day 10. From day 11 to day 18, mice were administered with saline and confined to any one chamber on alternate days. On day 19, a CPP test was again carried out to test whether ethanol-induced CPP was extinguished. On day 20, mice were treated with mecamylamine (0.1 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) or vehicle, 10 min before receiving a priming injection of ethanol (1 g/kg, i.p.) or vehicle (saline). Ten minutes after ethanol injection mice were placed in the apparatus for another 5 min test of CPP (reinstatement).

sec.title: Experiment 4: influence of mecamylamine on the stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP
sec.p: A separate group of animals were conditioned to 2 g/kg ethanol or saline as described above and given a 5 min CPP test on day 10. From day 11 to day 18, mice were administered with saline and confined to any one chamber on alternate days. On day 19, a CPP test (extinction) was again carried out to test whether ethanol-induced CPP was extinguished. On day 20, mice were treated with mecamylamine (0.1 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) or vehicle, 10 min before subjecting to either forced swim stress or restraint stress (15 min). Ten minutes after stress, mice were placed in the apparatus for another 5 min test of CPP (reinstatement).

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: The results are expressed as a mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). Data were analyzed using one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey’s multiple comparison tests as described earlier (Kuzmin et al., 2003; Biala and Budzynska, 2008). p < 0.05 was considered statistically significant in all cases.

sec.title: Effect of mecamylamine on the acquisition of ethanol-induced CPP
sec.p: The average time spent in ethanol paired black and white chambers during test was indifferent (black: 165.25 ± 11.03 seconds; and white: 162.75 ± 10.52 seconds). One-way ANOVA revealed that mice administered with mecamylamine (0.1, 1.0, and 10 µg/mouse, i.c.v.), 10 min prior to each ethanol (2.0 g/kg, i.p.) injection on days 2, 4, 6, and 8 (during development of ethanol-induced CPP), spent a significantly shorter time in the ethanol paired chamber during the CPP test on day 10 [F(7,56) = 9.611, p < 0.0001] when compared with the vehicle-treated group (Figure 1). Post hoc test further revealed that mecamylamine (1 or 10 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) significantly and dose dependently reduced the development of ethanol-induced CPP response (p < 0.01 and p < 0.001, respectively). Lower dose of mecamylamine (0.1 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) also had some inhibitory influence, but failed to attain statistical significant level. Further, repeated administration of mecamylamine had no influence on the number of crossings between the compartments [F(7,56) = 1.049, p = 0.4082] (Figure 1). Post hoc test further revealed that repeated administration of mecamylamine did not show any preference to any chamber when administered in the saline-conditioned group.

caption.p: Effect of mecamylamine on the acquisition of ethanol-induced conditioned place preference. Each value represents the mean ± SEM (n = 7 or 8). *p < 0.001 versus [(vehicle + saline in conditioning) + (vehicle + saline in testing)]; #p < 0.01, @p < 0.001 versus [(vehicle + ethanol in conditioning) + (vehicle + saline in testing)] treated group (one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparison test).

sec.title: Effect of mecamylamine on the expression of ethanol-induced CPP
sec.p: One-way ANOVA indicated that acute mecamylamine treatment significantly decreased the expression of ethanol-induced CPP [F(7,56) = 10.39, p < 0.0001] (Figure 2). On day 10 (test day), mice treated with vehicle plus saline (12.5 ml/kg, i.p.) in ethanol (2.0 g/kg, i.p.) conditioned group, spent a significantly longer time in the ethanol paired chamber (p < 0.001) when compared with vehicle treatment in the saline-conditioned mice, indicated the development of CPP to the effect of ethanol (2.0 g/kg, i.p.), whereas mecamylamine (0.1, 1.0, and 10 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) treatment on day 10 prior to saline, exhibited significantly reduced time spent in the ethanol-conditioned chamber as compared with vehicle treatment (p < 0.01, p < 0.001, p < 0.001, respectively). Moreover, mecamylamine treatment had no significant influence on the number of crossings between the compartments [F(7,56) = 0.7919, p = 0.5972] (Figure 2).

caption.p: Effect of mecamylamine on the expression of ethanol-induced conditioned place preference. Each value represents the mean ± SEM (n = 7 or 8). *p < 0.001 versus [(vehicle + saline in conditioning) + (vehicle + saline in testing)]; #p < 0.01, @p < 0.001 versus [(vehicle + ethanol in conditioning) + (vehicle + saline in testing)] treated group (one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparison test).

sec.title: Effect of mecamylamine on the reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP
sec.p: The priming injection of ethanol (1.0 g/kg, i.p.) injected 1 day after the extinction trial (day 20), completely reinstated the extinguished ethanol-induced CPP, whereas pretreatment with nicotinic acetylcholine receptors antagonist, mecamylamine, significantly inhibited the priming effect of ethanol in ethanol-conditioned mice [F(10,64) = 15.03, p < 0.0001] (Figure 3). Post-hoc individual comparisons test indicated a significant (p < 0.01) effect of mecamylamine (0.1 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) on ethanol reinstated ethanol-induced CPP. Moreover, these changes in CPP were unrelated to changes in locomotor activity as indicated by no change in number of crossings between the compartments (Figure 3). Post hoc test revealed that acute treatment with mecamylamine did not shown any preference to any chamber when administered in the saline-conditioned group. Further, administration of ethanol (1.0 g/kg) on reinstatement day in saline-conditioned animals had no significant influence when compared with saline (p > 0.05).

caption.p: Effects of mecamylamine (0.1 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) on the reinstatement of ethanol (2.0 g/kg, i.p.) conditioned place preference caused by a priming dose of ethanol (1.0 g/kg, i.p.). Place preference procedure performed thrice after conditioning, i.e. test, extinction trial and reinstatement. Data represent mean ± SEM (n = 6 or 7) and are expressed as the time spent in ethanol paired chamber. *p < 0.001 versus saline-conditioned control group receiving either saline or ethanol (1.0 g/kg) injection on the reinstatement day; &p < 0.01 versus ethanol-conditioned group given ethanol injection on the reinstatement day (one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparison test).

sec.title: Influence of mecamylamine on the stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP
sec.p: Mice subjected to a single session of either forced swim stress or restraint stress (15 min), 1 day after the extinction trial (day 20), completely reinstated the extinguished ethanol-induced CPP (Figures 4 and 5, respectively), whereas pretreatment with nicotinic acetylcholine receptors antagonist, mecamylamine, significantly inhibited the priming effect of stressors in ethanol-treated mice [forced swim stress: F(9,57) = 38.56, p < 0.0001; restraint stress: F(9,59) = 18.19, p < 0.0001]. Post hoc individual comparisons test indicated a significant effect of mecamylamine at a dose of (0.1 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) (p < 0.001) on stress reinstated ethanol-induced CPP. Moreover, these changes in CPP after stress and mecamylamine treatment in the stressed group were unrelated to changes in locomotor activity as indicated by no change in number of crossings between the compartments (Figures 4 and 5). Further, animals subjected to stress on reinstatement day in saline-conditioned animals had no significant influence when compared with saline (p > 0.05).

caption.p: Effects of mecamylamine (0.1 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) on the reinstatement of ethanol (2.0 g/kg, i.p.) conditioned place preference caused by priming of single session of forced swim stress. Place preference procedure performed thrice after conditioning, i.e. test, extinction trial and reinstatement. Data represent mean ± SEM (n = 6 or 7) and are expressed as the time spent in the ethanol paired chamber. *p < 0.001 versus saline-conditioned control group receiving either saline injection or subjected to forced swim stress on the reinstatement day; &p < 0.001 versus ethanol-conditioned group exposed to forced swim stress on the reinstatement day (one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparison test).

Effects of mecamylamine (0.1 µg/mouse, i.c.v.) on the reinstatement of ethanol (2.0 g/kg, i.p.) conditioned place preference caused by priming of single session of restraint stress. Place preference procedure performed thrice after conditioning, i.e. test, extinction trial and reinstatement. Data represent mean ± SEM (n = 6 or 7) and are expressed as the time spent in the ethanol paired chamber. *p < 0.001 versus saline-conditioned control group receiving either saline injection or subjected to restraint stress on the reinstatement day; &p < 0.001 versus ethanol-conditioned group exposed to restraint stress on the reinstatement day (one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparison test).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The main aim of the present study was to determine the role of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP along with the acquisition, expression and reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP. Our results demonstrate that mecamylamine blocks the forced swim and restraint stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP. Further, it also blocked the development and expression of ethanol-induced CPP in mice. Earlier reports have shown that mecamylamine blocks the ethanol-plus nicotine-induced CPP (Zarrindast et al., 2010) and morphine- or nicotine-induced reinstatement of nicotine-induced CPP (Rezayof et al., 2007; Pascual et al., 2009; Biala et al., 2010). Thus, the results of the present study further add to the growing literature that nicotinic acetylcholine receptors are involved in the stress- and ethanol-induced activation of ethanol relapse.

CPP is a simple non-invasive method, compatible with classical Pavlovian conditioning (Itzhak and Martin, 2002). In this paradigm, animals are initially trained to associate a distinctive environment with drug injection, and a different environment with vehicle injection. Following training, animals spend more time in the drug-paired environment, when given a choice between the two environments on a drug-free test day. This acquired preference can be abolished by daily injections of saline (alternatively, the days without any injections) with free access to both drug-paired and saline-paired environments. It was found that after extinction, the non-contingent exposure to the drug of abuse acts to renew the significance and attractiveness of the drug-related environmental stimuli (the incentive value of drug-associated cues), drawing the animal to approach and remain in the presence of the drug-related stimuli, resulting in the reinstatement of the CPP (Mueller and Stewart, 2000; Parker and McDonald, 2000). This animal model has been used to measure the appetitive value of different stimuli as well as to evaluate relapse to drug abuse. Thus, the results in the present study hint towards the possible use of mecamylamine in treatment of alcoholism, especially to aid patients from relapse.

Previous studies have reported that various stressors like intermittent unpredictable foot-shock, restraint, conditioned fear, social defeat, swim stress, and tail pinch reinstate the drug-induced CPP in rodents (for reviews see Aguilar et al., 2009; Shalev et al., 2010). However, herein we have shown that forced swim stress and restraint stress reinstate the ethanol-induced CPP. Further, the results also revealed that the lower dose of ethanol (lower than conditioning), which in an ethanol-naïve animal failed to induce significant place preference (data not shown), reinstate the ethanol-induced CPP, which is well in accordance with earlier reports (Shoblock et al., 2011). There is a large body of experimental reports demonstrating reliable ethanol-induced CPP in inbred and outbred mice (Cunningham et al., 1991; Crabbe et al., 1992; Cunningham, 1995; Risinger and Oakes, 1996; Bhutada et al., 2010a). In the present study, ethanol at a dose of 2.0 g/kg produced the maximal place conditioning effect in male albino Swiss mice (effects of other doses not shown). Reinstatement of CPP has also been demonstrated in Swiss mice with ethanol in earlier studies (Kuzmin et al., 2003; Font et al., 2008). In the present study, a single session of forced swim stress or restraint stress was able to reinstate ethanol-induced CPP when mice were tested 10 min after the stressor. The ability of either single or multiple sessions of forced swim stress or restraint stress are reported to induce reinstatement of cocaine- and morphine-induced CPP and drug-seeking behavior (McLaughlin et al., 2003; 2006; Kreibich and Blendy, 2004; Ribeiro Do Couto et al., 2006; Carey et al., 2007).

Stress is an important factor precipitating relapse in otherwise abstinent alcoholics (Brown et al., 1995). However, the development of medications to specifically treat stress-induced relapse is problematic because many anxiety medications, such as benzodiazepines, are addictive. Moreover, the approved medicine for treatment of alcoholism involves opioidergic mechanism, and reportedly modulates the reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP and ethanol self-administration (Le et al., 1999; Kuzmin et al., 2003). Interestingly, results of the present study revealed that mecamylamine blocked the ethanol-induced as well as stress-induced reinstatement of ethanol- CPP, which indicate that mecamylamine may have therapeutic potential in alcoholism.

A variety of neurotransmitters including dopamine have been reported to modulate ethanol self-administration, place preference, and reinstatement of place preference and self-administration. The literature suggest a critical role for dopamine acting via D1, D2, and D3 receptors in the nucleus accumbens in the reinstatement of responding for ethanol cues, and antagonist of these receptors are reported to block the ethanol reinstatement responses (Liu and Weiss, 2002; Vengeliene et al., 2006; Chaudhri et al., 2009). Interestingly, earlier studies have shown that mecamylamine delivered systemically or directly into the ventral tegmental area blocks elevation of ethanol-mediated dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens (Larsson et al., 2002, 2004). Recently, it is also reported that mecamylamine significantly reduces the number of DAergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area that were activated by repeated exposure to ethanol (Hendrickson et al., 2009). These reports indicate the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors modulate the dopaminergic neurotransmission and thereby exert the effects on ethanol-induced CPP.

Furthermore, it is reported that repeated administration of ethanol results in a long-lasting increase in the activity of the NR2B-NMDARs in the brain and inhibition of glutamate neurotransmission (NR2B-NMDARs activity) significantly decreases operant self-administration of ethanol and reduces ethanol-priming-induced reinstatement of ethanol-seeking behavior and relapse (Siggins et al., 2003; Backstrom and Hyytia, 2004; Bachteler et al., 2005; Wang et al., 2010). Mecamylamine is reported to non-competitively inhibit NMDA receptors (O’Dell and Christensen, 1988; Fu et al., 2008). In addition, nicotinic acetylcholine receptors antagonists, including mecamylamine, block NMDA-induced behavioral effects and exhibit NMDA receptor antagonist-like effects in experimental animals (McDonough and Shih, 1995). Furthermore, it is also well established that certain types of NMDA receptor antagonists (channel blockers) potently bind to nicotinic receptors and may act as nicotinic receptor antagonists (for reviews, see Zakharova et al., 2005). Therefore, the modulation of NMDA and/or nACh receptors in the effects of mecamylamine during the blockade of reinstatement of ethanol-induced CPP cannot be ruled out.

In conclusion, mecamylamine administration prevented the development and expression of ethanol-induced place conditioning as well as the reinstatement of ethanol CPP induced by ethanol itself as well as by restraint stress or forced swim stress in ethanol-conditioned mice, which implicates cholinergic nicotinic receptors. However, in the present context, the participation of other neurotransmitter systems in this effect cannot be ruled out.
